awd_titl_txt: Building Capacity to Develop STEM Teacher Leaders in Montana Rural and American Indian Schools
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to serve the national need of building capacity to develop high-quality science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) teacher leaders in rural and American Indian reservation communities. Like other rural states, Montana has a shortage of high-quality STEM teacher leaders in many geographically isolated, STEM-underrepresented, and high-needs schools and communities, particularly on and near Montana’s seven American Indian reservations. High-quality STEM teacher leaders can make a huge difference—inspiring young students to learn STEM content knowledge and pursue STEM careers, which ultimately broadens the diversity of the country’s STEM workforce. To develop high-quality STEM teacher leaders, qualified practicing STEM teachers must be recruited, trained, retained and provided ongoing support to develop their teaching competencies and hone their leadership skills.

This project at Montana State University will assess the needs of STEM teachers in potential partner schools on or near four reservations (Flathead, Blackfeet, Northern Cheyenne, and Crow) while building a network of collaborators within and beyond the university. Together, these partners will develop effective methods for recruiting and selecting experienced and exemplary STEM teachers to become teacher leaders; and identify or recommend a meaningful, culturally sustaining teacher leadership development model appropriate for high-need rural and reservation communities. Our ultimate goal is to build the capacity to support a cohort of dedicated, high-quality and culturally sustaining teacher leaders who can implement and develop exemplary practices for supporting rural and American Indian students. The findings and suggested practices generated from this project will advance our knowledge and enhance our expertise on creating scaffolds to develop experienced, exemplary STEM teachers to become teacher leaders in high-need rural and minority school districts. This Capacity Building project is supported through the Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program. The Noyce program supports talented STEM undergraduate majors and professionals to become effective K-12 STEM teachers and experienced, exemplary K-12 teachers to become STEM master teachers in high-need school districts. It also supports research on the effectiveness and retention of K-12 STEM teachers in high-need school districts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The capacity-building project successfully met its goals, laying the foundation for the Noyce Track 3 project, "Rural and American Indian School Educators as Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics Leaders (RAISE STEM Leaders)," which was awarded in July 2024 (Award No. 23451861). The project focused on four key goals:

Goal 1: Conduct Needs Assessments

To better understand the challenges and needs of STEM educators, needs assessments were conducted using three methods:

  • Interviews – Informal discussions with school leaders and teachers helped build trust and identify key concerns.
  • 2023 STEM Summer Institute Survey – Thirty-one teachers provided insights into student, school, and teacher needs.
  • 2024 MTF Application Responses – Applicants shared challenges in STEM pedagogy, identified needed supports, and suggested strategies for improving student engagement and achievement.

Goal 2: Strengthen Partnerships with Rural and American Indian Schools

Stakeholder interviews and school visits in June 2023 helped identify faculty needs and district resources. As leadership changes and shifting teacher interests influenced the partnerships, recruitment efforts evolved. By the end of this project, prospective Master Teaching Fellows (MTFs) were recruited from the following partner districts:

  • Browning and Cut Bank School Districts near or within the Blackfeet Reservation
  • Polson, Ronan, and Superior School Districts near or within the Flathead American Indian Reservation
  • Pryor and Hardin School Districts near or within the Crow Reservation
  • Saint Labre School near the Northern Cheyenne Reservation

Goal 3: Develop Evidence-Based Recruitment and Selection Methods

Discussions with project teams, school partners, and teachers refined the selection criteria for Master Teaching Fellows (MTFs). The application process was designed to assess candidates' skills, knowledge, and commitment to both STEM education and culturally sustaining pedagogy. 

Goal 4: Develop a Teacher Leadership Model

The project adopted Smylie and Eckert’s (2018) four teacher leadership components:

  1. Teacher Leadership Outcomes
  2. Teacher Leader Capacity
  3. Developmental Activities and Experiences
  4. Teacher Leader Practice

Fellow Orientation and Networking

The project team organized two in-person orientations and one online networking event for recruited prospective fellows.

  1. First Orientation: Integrated into the STEM Summer Institute at Montana State University from August 5–7, 2024, with an extended Noyce orientation on the afternoon of Friday, August 7.
  2. Second Orientation: Conducted as a session at the 2024 MFPE Educator Conference from October 17–18, 2024.
  3. Online Networking Event: Held on October 2, 2024, as a virtual check-in session for prospective MTFs to engage and network.

Dissemination of Project Results

The project results have been shared with communities of interest through multiple channels:

  1. Monthly Brainstorms! Newsletter – Issued by the Science Math Resource Center at Montana State University (MSU), featuring recruitment updates and project highlights.
  2. MSU News Coverage – Featured in an article about the new $3 million Noyce grant supporting STEM teachers in rural, underserved Montana communities (see https://www.montana.edu/news/24125/new-3-million-grant-at-montana-state-to-support-dozens-of-stem-teachers-in-rural-underserved-areas-of-montana)
  3. Conference Presentations:
  • Poster Presentation: "Building Capacity to Develop STEM Teacher Leaders" at the 2024 Noyce Summit in Washington, DC.
  • NSF Noyce Master Teaching Fellows Gathering & Luncheon – Held at the 2024 MFPE Educator Conference on October 18, 2024, where Montana STEM teachers outside the Noyce MTF program also participated.

 


Last Modified: 03/02/2025
Modified by: Fenqjen Luo
